p.s: During their conversation in which Amir tries to give some sensible pieces of advice to Abe they get into an intense fight that reveals a lot about the relationship between them.
It also becomes apparent that their relaitionshiprelationship changes throughout the scene.
At first Abe seems to look up to his uncle as he comes to him for help in a very difficult situation (cf. l. 1).
Later on he reveals that his uncle has been a role model to him (cf. ll. 65-68).
When he tells his uncle that he laughed when he found out he hesitates (cf. l. 4).
From this it can be concluded that Abe has doughtsdoubts about the decision to come to Amir and also that he fears Amir's reaction.
The fact that he is able to estimate his uncle's reaction shows that they know each other very well.
Even though Amir knows that Abe did not mean to laugh he asks him whether he was trying to antagonize the FBIFederal Bureau of Investigation (cf. l. 7).
It becomes apparent that Amir sees himself in the position to lecture Abe but alsalso that Amir is uncertain whether Abe really did not mean to laugh.

When they go on to discuss Abe's assumption that the American government wants to pressure him into working for them and Amir does not state a clear opinion Abe seems disappointed and gets a little bit agressiveaggressive (cf. ll. 10-14).
When Amir calls the lawyer of Imam Fareed's case he does not tell Abe what he is doing at first, which shows that he is looking down on Abe and does not treat him like a fellow but like a child.
That Amir tries to take the role of a parent becomes apparent once more, when he tries to advice him in a very careful way (cf. ll. 21-22).

Later on in the conversation Abe becomes very forceful and tries to provoceprovoke his uncle by asking him what he would do if the FBIFederal Bureau of Investigation had asked him to work for them (cf. l. 28).
When Amir tries to avoid an answer Amir insists on an answer and does not accept his unclesuncle's decision not to make a statement (cf. ll. 28-30).
At this point Abe is clearly losing respect and he feelfeels in his doughtsdoubts about Amir.
Amir tries to stay calm and considers his choice of words very carefully (cf. l. 31) as he knows Abe is easily provocedprovoked at this point.
Abe reveals his doughtsdoubts and states that he knew it was a mistake Amir (cf. l. 35).
He becomes more and more defiant and questions whether it was even worth it to immigrate to the USA (cf. l. 40-41).
Amir at first tries to talk sense into Abe but Abe gets very personal and loses respect (cf. l. 50) as one can see when he confronts Amir with what he did to his Ex-wifeex-wife Emily.
Abe starts judging Amir's life which apparently is something he has not done before because Amir seems suprisedsurprised and also irritated by this bahaviourbehaviour (cf. l. 55).
But Abe continues to critisize Amir for his attitude towards islamIslam and he projects all his frustration onto him (cf. l. 55-57).
As a reaction Amir loses his temper and criticizes Abe's behaviour and his carelessness.
He cannot understand how Abe is not able to see what he sees.
Amir might also be hurt because he realizes that he is losing his nephew and also because Abe is not accepting his advice.
At this point their relashionshiprelationship has become very damaged.
Abe starts to get very unkind and angry but this shows his dissappointmentdisappointment because he was hoping that his uncle would support his opinion and instead he feels betrayed (cf. l. 63-70).
He is angry because his uncle used to be someone to look up to but this fight confirmed his fear that they do not see eye to eye anymore.

In the last few sentences Abe's frutrationfrustration that came up during all the discrimination he experienced comes out and he dislances himself from his uncle to live his religion in a more radical way (cf. ll. 70-75).

Coming to a conclusion it seems like Abe sought this conversation not only because he needed help but also because he was uncertain about the relationship with Amir and wanted to know wetherwhether his asumptionsassumptions were right.
At first they have respect for each other but during the fight Abe says things that are pobablyprobably not forgivebalforgivable.
Abe is annoyed by Amir always playing the Fatherrolefather role because he refuses to listen to Amir's advice.
While Amir used to be a role model for Abe and Abe tried to immitate him by also changing his name and dressing like an American he is not anymore than a disappointment to Abe.
